These commonsense rules changes will allow for the will of the majority to turn ideas into action and pass much-needed legislation.
The rules changes we are announcing today will make the House of Representatives work even better for the American people, and help remove the roadblocks to progress on these core priorities.
This November, voters not only asked for a new party at the helm, but asked for their core issues – health care, immigration, and infrastructure – to get solved.

I am pleased to report that, after months of constructive discussions, the Problem Solvers Caucus Democrats have reached an agreement to support Leader Pelosi so the Break the Gridlock rules changes will be adopted in January.

Like most of you, I’m sick and tired of the gridlock and obstructionism, when we have so much on the line. That’s why we are doing something about it for New Jersey and our country.

Again, in this era of divided government, we hope Leader Pelosi will join us in taking these concrete steps for change to help break the gridlock and pass meaningful legislation to fix health care, immigration, and infrastructure.

Most Americans would look at these proposals and tell you they're just common sense, and expect Congress to already work that way. Unfortunately, years of partisanship and ideologically-motivated obstructionism have undercut our governing institutions.

3. Every Congress, each Member will be allowed to introduce one bill for debate and a vote on a committee on which he/she serves. The bill must be germane to that committee's jurisdiction and have at least one cosponsor from the other party.
2. When an amendment (a proposed change) to a bill has at least 20 Democratic and 20 Republican cosponsors, it will get a debate and a vote when that bill is considered on the floor.
1. When a bill receives 290 cosponsors (or three-fifths of Congress), it will go to the House floor for debate and a timely vote.

We are asking Leader Pelosi to publicly support the following ideas of the “Break the Gridlock” rules changes that we first proposed in June to help spur immediate action on health care, immigration, and infrastructure:

The bottom line is this: We need real rules reform to get bipartisan legislation heard — not just more committees to study the problem. Bipartisan legislation with broad support deserves honest debate and a simple up-or-down vote.

If we are going to get anything done and move New Jersey forward, we will have to work together. With health care, immigration, infrastructure, and jobs on the line, we simply can’t afford two more years of gridlock.
The reality is that we are now living in an era of divided government. Come January, Democrats will lead the House, but the Senate and White House will continue to be controlled by Republicans.
Our rules proposal isn't about changing leadership; it's about changing a system that stymies the will of the common sense majority.

For six months now, the Problem Solvers has focused on changing the House rules, so we can finally get action on infrastructure (fixing our roads, tunnels and bridges), health care (premiums down), and immigration reform (allowing DREAMERs to stay and keeping our borders secure).
As with anything, there’s plenty of misinformation, so I thought I’d clarify a few things.

I’ve heard from many of you about my fight to change some of the House rules to get bipartisan legislation accomplished. The outpouring of support for the Caucus' effort has been incredible. Thank you.
